The discussion has been interesting, but it is based on a false premise. From previous discussions with HeavenBound I am quite cognizant of the fact that she believes that evolutionary biology, cosmology, geology, nuclear physics, and other fields of science are attacks on "Christianity." Of course, a rational person knows that it isn't true. It seems to me from previous experience that HeavenBound is of the opinion that scientific objections to young earth creationism are attempts to discredit christianity. What hubris on her part. Given the hundreds of sects of christianity that exist in just the U.S., and given that many of them accept evolutionary theory (officially all of the "main line" Christian sects do), to claim that her particular sect is the only true version is ludicrous.
 
 It is especially silly given the recent origen of christian fundamentalism. The 12 pamphlets upon which fundamentalist christianity are based were written between 1910 and 1915. They were a backlash against science - not only evolutionary theory, but cosmology, physics, geology, and on and on. And yet, fundamentalists claim that they are the only arbiters of what is true christianity.
 
 And young earth creationism as a tenet of "christianity" is even worse. It came about in the 1960s when Henry Morris adopted the flood geology of the 7th Day Adventist, George McCready Price. Flood geology was then and still is bogus. Fundamentalists rechristened Price's opinions as "creation science" and we were off to the courts.
 
 You see, what HeavenBound considers attacks on "christianity" aren't. I don't have a problem with Christianity. I do have a problem with those who represent it as science. I have a problem with those who want to impose their religion on all students in science classes. I do have a problem with fundamentalist efforts to impose their religion on everyone through prayer at public school events.
 
 HeavenBound or any of the other fundamentalist (my religion is the TROOTH!) debaters should take a step back and consider what they are advocating. If you don't want your religion judged as science, then stop trying to pretend that it is. Nobody really gives a rat's tootie what you want to believe, most certainly not scientists. If you don't want your beliefs to be challenged, then stop presenting them as either scientific or rational. To do so is an indication that your faith is weak. You seem to have a need to justify it beyond faith.
 
 So in response to HeavenBound's OP, none of the efforts to discredit anything about Christianity are true. What is true is that HeavenBound cannot reconcile her faith with reality and science.
 
 The answer is to stop representing your faith as science. Teach it in you home, teach it in your private school. Stand on the corner and scream at anyone who passes by. Good for you!

 It is this Comforter who can bring about the assurance of His presence and love; who can give those that believe the evidence they need to keep holding on. Without His Spirit we would only have what we could get naturally, which has proven time and again, not near enough.
 
 And who has not been in a rough spot and needed just that one brief touch of something physical, something that they can look at, feel, absorb in the natural? I know I have. But, I quickly realize that even at best, the natural things are temporary and soon I'll be hungry again. I can't explain every facet of my faith or how it comes to my aid when I least expect it, but I do know where it comes from. With that assurance it is just as if I have placed my hands in His...and not because I want to feel the scars, but because I want to feel Life - I crave it.
 
 If it were not for the fact that I have felt His Spirit and seen what He has done for my family and me physically, then I would be wondering why in the world someone would want to be a part of something that they can't see...
 
 I hope this helps

when it comes down to time honored texts that have been carefully preserved, i like to point to the Mahabharatha. It is considered the longest epic ever written, spanning thousands of verses in 18 volumes. It is also extremely well preserved; it's error rate (in comparison to the original) is said to be so little that there are but a few words in question. The epic is also written as history. It is based on two rival monarchies, the Pandavas and the Kauravas, and their 14+ years of bitter struggle which ends with a final 18 war.
 
 By all accounts, this book has the same credibility of time honored text as any religious text. But examination of its content reveal "occurances" not feasable in the time of its writing (5000BC, which makes it older that even the bible). There are instances of flying aircrafts, explosive missles, biological warfare capable of putting to sleep thousands of soldiers, and even force fields. Does it's honor of age give it enough credibility to be accounted as History?
 
 There is no doubt that there was some major war. In fact, the war might have been very similar to the one described in the Mahabharata. There is a lot of proof to its truth, such as a well documented family tree from which even descendants today can refer too. Just like the Bible, the Mahabharata has many proofs and facts to verify its claims. However, its plot line, though it has a possibility of occuring today, is very unlikely of happening in the period it was written.
 
 [edit] The time of writing in only about 200 B.C. It's events are supposed to be of 5000BC.
